page.title: 20Local Town History
page.content: Stevenage lies on chalk in a valley between the Chilterns and the East Anglian Heights. The Saxons settled in the area and have given names which can still be recognised today. The original name was Stigenace (meaning strong oak) from which it has changed to Stevenage. The village grew into a local market and by 1448 Henry VI confirmed the market charter. Expansion continued as a result of the improvements to the main road (The Great North Road) connecting London to the North. From the Eighteenth Century onwards the settlement became an important coaching centre. By the end of the Second World War the population reached almost 7000. In 1946 the Government passed the New Towns Act to relieve pressure from London and to provide people with a more attractive environment in which to live. The population is now 74000
